comments.commentBody:
- "Ben, by that standard, neither should the right to own property, since one person's possession of property necessarily limits another's right to property."

Your reasoning is deeply flawed. The right to own property is not an entitlement, as the proposed "rights" to healthcare, food, et al, which stipulate that resources be *taken* (under threat of force) from some so that something may be *given* to others. Property ownership rights are predicated on acquiring the means to acquire property (through work, wise investment...or even dumb luck in some cases). It does not entail forcefully taking property opwned by one and giving it to another.

This is a great step towards educating straight people not to hate their children.  Gays are born, not made, and if you don't like gays or think they don't deserve equal rights, don't have children.  there is a 1 in 10 chance your child will be gay according to the only credible study on human sexuality to tackle the subject with anonymous surveys, not live interviews.  How many married men are going to tell another man he is gay, even if the man promises the interview is anonymous.  Human nature tells us that won't happen.  Yale didn't get that fine point.  A few years ago David Brooks wrote a piece that said straight people were moving to small towns in Colorado to escape the gay rights that were being "shoved down their throats" - why do straight people insist on using that term?  I hope Mr. Brooks visits his idyllic Colorado Straightsville in about 21 years.  Near the downtown bus terminal he may find a small bar with a neon rainbow flag Budweiser sign in the window.  Gay children like to knock back a cold one before hopping on a bus and leaving their disapproving families forever.   If Mr. Brooks had a gay child would he love him/her?  We he go to his child's same-sex wedding?  Of course not.  Some people are too mired in hate to change with the times.  I hope I'm around 21 years from now to see how beautiful the world is when gays are accepted by their families.
Is that why the price of Gasoline has gone up to nearly all time highs of almost $4.00/gal. in urban areas?

On the contrary  U.S.don't need so much staff there .Intention of U.S. is fulfilled .Your multinational corporations strongly  control the oil well of Iraq . Why you want to keep unnecessary staff there ?

I used to work at one of those tax preparation centers and I saw so many cohabiting couples come in. The couple would have a combined income where they wouldn’t qualify for the Earned Income Tax Credit if they were married, but since the mom was unmarried, she could file as “Head of Household” and claim it. Same thing happens for things like food stamps, Medicaid, WIC, and so on. The income limit for “married” is not twice that for “Head of Household” so there is a major financial disincentive to make the relationship legal.
So well said.
God has given man the will to choose and so you choose wisely
Well said Chris

To all of you who keep holding up the BIble, God, and religion as your "rational basis" for denying rights to those who do not believe what you believe, how many times do you have to be reminded that in this country and under the Constitution you do not have a right to force those beliefs on anyone?  And you certainly do not have a right to deny others rights that you enjoy simply because you do not favor the way they choose to pursue life, liberty, and happiness... this is not a "Christian nation" - this is a secular nation that allows you the freedom worship and believe as you choose... but it DOES NOT allow you to impose those beliefs on anyone or any institution of this country... allowing me to marry whom I choose IN NO WAY affects or harms your ability to marry whom you choose or to believe what you want to continue to believe... as many wise forefathers before us said, with great rights comes great responsibility... if those of you who continue down this path of wielding your religion as justification for intolerance and denial of rights to others then your very own right to believe and worship as you choose must then itself be called into question... this is NOT a "mob rule" country where my rights or anyone else's are left up to a vote by the majority!  This country does not allow for suppression and denial of human dignity and rights for me or anyone else by a ballot box vote by whatever majority!

One by one the blown-out-of-proportion positions held by the GOP values voters and their paid evangelical leaders hit the dirt. These are all a part "of the broken windows of the Republican idea factory."

Their stuff does not make sense and does not pass an all-sides-of-the-story test. But it's the GOP MO.

Say no to political evangelism. Search Google for more.

Mr. Doyle, your personal impressions are not the point. The 98% figure has been given repeatedly in the press and is backed by data. But even if it’s 85%, as you claim, it hardly negates Kay’s point.

Also, and I think this has been overlooked: No one is making anyone use birth control, simply giving the same benefits to all who CHOOSE to, regardless of religious affiliation or place of employment!

Believe as you like, but don’t confuse it with access to health care.

I suppose pro choicers would defend the right to abort a fetus that might be a homosexual. Right? Or should that killing be limited to straight fetuses.
Well?

SBKF has done some good for some women and that is some good.
However, its obvious they are not the altruistic organization many believed and that is the real shame - to those who blindly trusted their actions and intentions - to those they should have focused on serving and to those who worked so hard to raise donations and support them.

Its a shame faulty humans were in control and their deeds became known to everyone else.

I'm not sure SBKF will ever fully recover. I'm positive it will not if Brinker does not follow Handel in resigning. Brinker has attempted to distance herself from the original decision and that is just not the situation - as most understand. I'm no fan of Handel's politics, but Brinker also receives failing grades for the lack of honesty and responsibility she has demonstrated.

Brinker is self-serving and has not rewarded the loyalty of donors with the integrity due.

As usual, political polarization rears its ugly head.  Everyone has a spin based on their politics and ideology.  Has anyone noted the huge amount of good that the Komen Foundation has done in supporting important research that has saved the lives of thousands of women.  Before we declare the evil (either for their support of Planned Parenthood or the withdrawal of support) let's remember that almost everything else they have done has been directed toward helping prevent and treat breast cancer, a disease that indiscriminately attacks liberals, conservatives, pro-choice and pro-life supporters.  Instead of making this an opportunity to vilify whichever decision you disagree with and the people who made it, take a step back, congratulate Komen for all of their successes and pick them or another organization to support to help the fight against breast cancer.
He’s just trying to out-santorum Rick Santorum--which apparently has not worked in Minnesota, Missouri, and Colorado :-)

Easily. Its called campaign organization. Which Santorum does not have. Ron Paul certainly does. Romney has organization but no passion. Which leaves.... nobody. Because Gingrich has only a big debt and the Southern electorate.

People who attend the caucuses support who they want, so Santorum has to get his backers to actually show up at the caucus.
The vote in Missouri was almost 60% less than in 2008 when the primary actually counted. Who do those people want to back? Gingrinch wasn't even on the ballot, but people can vote for him at the caucuses.
Given the magnitude of Santorum's victory in Missouri, is there any way the state's Republican caucus goers can really award the state's delegates to anyone else?

Excuse me, but the equal-protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendnent applies nationwide, as it's part of the FEDERAL Constitution. The high court almost never fails to take up significant cases involving the Constitution.

Kennedy is one of the most balanced and least ideological justices we have had in some time. I would prefer that the Court's support for basic constitutional principles could be more broad-based, but I am glad that the likely swing vote will be Kennedy's.

freeword7 - that's not entirely true.

This isn't just about California and its state constitution. The 9th Circuit ruled "that the disparate treatment of married couples and domestic partners since the passage of Proposition 8 violated the Constitution’s Equal Protection Clause. "

Because the Equal Protection Clause - the 14 Amendment - of the US Consititution was the ground for the 9th Circuit's decision, the Supreme Court could decide to grant cert because of the case's national implications/constitutional concerns and take the case if and when it is appealed to it. The Court doesn'tt have to grant cert. here, but I think it is very likely that they do, considering the fact that other states have legalized same-sex marriage, or are considering doing so like NJ.
Excuse me, but lesbians can most certainly give birth. You obviously haven't heard of in vitro fertilization and artificial insemination.

Tim R. Mortiss, Tacoma, WA -

Can you site those "heated" positions? I think your memory fails you. You're probably more likely just recalling the fears of a minority trying to feel the power of it's voice in the face of overwhelming discrimination - they did used to haul gays off in paddy wagons, you realize.

I have seen variations of this argument trotted out today as a last desperate attempt to try to make supporters of same sex marriage look logically inconsistent.  However, there is a major flaw in your ploy:  Our inheritance laws are based upon clearly traceable lineage.  In addition, incestuous marriages are not banned only for public health reasons, but also for reasons of emotional trauma. They also have absolutely nothing in common with same sex unions, which of course are unions of people who are not closely related, just as heterosexual unions have been.  To trot out the brothers marrying or father and sons marrying as a supposed fly in the ointment ignores the realities in hopes of a gotcha.  It doesn't work.
Childless heterosexual couples like other animal species have the potential of procreating, something not possible from the union between a woman and a woman.

No, the high court has little choice but to decide this case, because there are also legal challenges to the federal Defense of Marriage Act. Moreover, the Ninth Circuit covers NINE western states, not just California. Its rulings apply to all nine states in its jurisdiction.
Why don't you summarize it for us?

John:
Congratulations on your long term loving relationship. Do you think a long term genuine loving relationship among three guys should be recognized. If not why not?
Maybe we should come up with a test to find out if a fetus is going to become a soccer mom instead?
The majority of the citizens of the United States believe it is about what is wrong and irrational.
If a genetic test is developed to determine what someone's sexual orientation is, we'll all be surprised to find out that it's probably just one gene: bisexual!

I agree. A characteristic of the Roberts Court, at least before Citizens United, was to decide only the necessary issue.  Narrow decisions are what we expect from them most of the time and they might not even take this case because the appellate court decision is itself narrowly drawn.
